metadata.feature_description: Provides connector metadata including name, icon, category for display in the connectors management UI

steps.expected: Connectors page loads with list of available connectors
steps.actual: Connectors page loaded successfully showing all available connectors in a table format

steps.action: Locate Google Tag Manager in the connectors list
steps.expected: Google Tag Manager connector is visible with display name 'Google Tag Manager'
steps.actual: Google Tag Manager connector row displays 'GOOGLE TAG MANAGER' as the display name (uppercase styling applied by UI)

steps.action: View the Google Tag Manager connector row in the connectors list
steps.expected: GTM icon is displayed next to the connector name
steps.actual: Blue diamond-shaped Google Tag Manager icon is displayed correctly in the connector row

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Test connector doesn't support multiple instances

steps.action: Review connectors list for Google Tag Manager entries
steps.expected: Only one Google Tag Manager connector appears in the list (no 'Add' or 'Create New' options)
steps.actual: Only a single Google Tag Manager connector row appears in the connectors list with a 'Connect' button, confirming single instance support

steps.action: Click Connect to expand the GTM configuration panel
steps.expected: Configuration panel expands without option to create additional instances
steps.actual: Configuration panel expands showing Container ID field and checkbox option, no option to create additional connector instances

observations: The UI does not display visible category groupings (Marketing, Content, Social) for connectors - all connectors are shown in a flat 'Configure Connections' list. The code confirms Type = ConnectorCategories.Marketting but this is not visually indicated in the UI.
The IsEngageConnector property is set to false in code, but there is no visual indicator in the UI to verify this. This property affects internal behavior rather than UI display.
Display name shows as 'GOOGLE TAG MANAGER' in uppercase, which appears to be UI styling applied to the 'Google Tag Manager' value from code.
